Award.AwardTitle: Advanced Interpenetrating Networks for Structural Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The implementation of structural polymers and fiber reinforced polymer composites in civil infrastructure, energy, aerospace, and automotive industries has been steadily gaining prominence. Epoxy resins are dominant materials used in structural applications due to their strength and stiffness. However, epoxy resins are also brittle and essentially elastic up to failure with little capacity for redistribution of stresses and dissipation of energy. The objective of this project is to develop tough epoxy resins through the synthesis and characterization of novel interpenetrating networks of traditional epoxy resins with polydicyclopentadiene, a commercially available polymer that is well-known to be ductile and tough. The hypothesis of this project is that an interpenetrating network will combine the advantageous properties of both of its constituents thereby exhibiting superior cracking and debonding behavior as compared to traditional structural epoxy resins. The knowledge gained in the development of these materials will provide a greater understanding of critical parameters governing interpenetrating network formation, structural evolution during the material preparation, and relationships between the material structure and macroscopic physical properties.

As engineers become more comfortable with the use of composites in structural applications, they are adopting thicker and larger structural components to meet the load requirements of more demanding applications. For example, some modern commercial airliners implement fiber reinforced polymer composites; similarly, glass fiber composites are commonly used to fabricate wind turbine blades. In civil infrastructure, thick, high modulus carbon fiber reinforced polymers have been investigated to repair and strengthen deteriorated steel structures. Despite their higher costs, epoxy resin adhesives are most commonly used to bond composite materials for structural applications. This research project will result in development of a new class of materials that maintain the advantageous properties of epoxy resins (high strength and stiffness), yet are also tough and resistant to fracturing. Educational programs will be closely integrated into the research objectives, including the development of a hands-on outreach program for K-12 students and participation of undergraduate and graduate students in the research, emphasizing retaining students in engineering and educating students on the impact of polymers on society.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The materials developed in this project have broad application in civil infrastructure, energy, aerospace, and automotive industries, and as structural adhesives and resins for structural composites composed of a polymer resin and reinforcement material (usually glass or carbon fibers). Epoxy resins are dominant resins used in composite applications due to their high strength and stiffness, yet are inherently brittle materials. This project has developed tough resins by combining the advantageous properties of epoxy resins with that of a polymer with higher toughness and ductility (i.e. extendibility), polydicyclopentadiene. The two materials are highly immiscible when combined together, and therefore form a particle phase of polydicyclopentadiene dispersed throughout the epoxy resin matrix. Control over the size of this dispersion yields the ability to manipulate other properties of these materials, which can be tuned over a wide range. 

Another aspect of this project has focused on replacing bisphenol A, the petroleum-derived source of epoxy resins, with sustainable and non-toxic feedstocks. Plant-based molecules have been identified which produce epoxy resins with comparable or enhanced properties compared to traditional bisphenol A-based epoxy resins. In addition, the incorporation of biobased molecules allowed for accelerated degradation in water. Traditional epoxy resins are not degradable and also cannot be recycled. Therefore, they reside in landfills after their useful lifetime. The use of degradable materials may provide additional end-of-life options, such as composting, for this important class of material.

Different types of structural adhesives with different properties are used to bond composite materials to metals in a wide range of applications in various industry sectors.  The research done in this study has also helped to quantitatively define which parameters are most important the overall bond performance of bonded joints between these dissimilar materials.  The traditional thinking has largely been that high-strength, low-toughness adhesives or high-toughness, low strength adhesives yield stronger bonded joints.  The research conducted through this project demonstrated that superior bond performance can be achieved by using adhesives that are moderately strong and moderately tough. The manufactured epoxy/polydicyclopentadiene blends were weaker and tougher than pure epoxy but stronger and less tough than pure polydicyclopentadiene.  However, the best performing blends provided joint strengths that were up to 37% and 124% greater than the strengths of joints that were made with pure epoxy or pure polydicyclopentadiene.  This research provided important insight into how to design adhesive blends to obtain optimum joint performance for certain applications in which dissimilar materials are bonded together.

 


Last Modified: 10/06/2017
Modified by: Megan L Robertson

Epoxy resins are dominant resins used in composite applications due to their high strength and stiffness, yet are inherently brittle materials. The two materials are highly immiscible when combined together, and therefore form a particle phase of polydicyclopentadiene dispersed throughout the epoxy resin matrix. Control over the size of this dispersion yields the ability to manipulate other properties of these materials, which can be tuned over a wide range. Another aspect of this project has focused on replacing bisphenol A, the petroleum-derived source of epoxy resins, with sustainable and non-toxic feedstocks. Plant-based molecules have been identified which produce epoxy resins with comparable or enhanced properties compared to traditional bisphenol A-based epoxy resins. Therefore, they reside in landfills after their useful lifetime. The use of degradable materials may provide additional end-of-life options, such as composting, for this important class of material. Different types of structural adhesives with different properties are used to bond composite materials to metals in a wide range of applications in various industry sectors. The manufactured epoxy/polydicyclopentadiene blends were weaker and tougher than pure epoxy but stronger and less tough than pure polydicyclopentadiene. This research provided important insight into how to design adhesive blends to obtain optimum joint performance for certain applications in which dissimilar materials are bonded together.
